messages.content: My knee hurts
I want to help you figure this out. Does it hurt during the warmup, only when you're pushing hard, or after you stop? That'll help me understand what might be going on.
I have pain in my leg
Let's narrow this down. Where exactly in your leg—front, back, inside, outside? And is it more of a sharp pain or a dull ache?
Something feels off
I hear you. Can you point to where it feels off? And when you say 'off'—is it discomfort, tightness, weakness, or something else?
My back is bothering me
That's worth paying attention to. Is it your lower back or upper back? And does it bother you more on the bike, or all the time?
I'm having hip issues
Let me understand better. Is it the front of your hip, the side, or deep in the joint? And does it happen during exercise or also at rest?
My foot goes numb when I ride
That's not uncommon but worth addressing. Does it happen early in rides or only after longer efforts? And is it the whole foot or specific areas like the toes?
I pulled something
Ouch—let's be careful with that. Where did you feel it pull, and did it happen suddenly during a specific movement?
My shoulder hurts after long rides
That can happen from bike position or tension. Is it more of an ache from holding position, or does it feel like something specific is irritated?
I have a niggle
Good that you're paying attention to it early. Where is it, and would you describe it as sharp, dull, tight, or something else?
My ankle is sore
Let me understand more. Is it sore from a specific incident, or has it come on gradually? And is it worse with activity or all the time?
I have pain when I pedal
That's important to sort out. Where do you feel it—knee, hip, foot? And does it happen throughout the pedal stroke or at a specific point?
My IT band is acting up
That can be frustrating. Is it mainly on the outside of your knee, or higher up toward your hip? And does it start immediately or develop over the course of a ride?
I have shin pain
Let's figure out what's going on. Is it along the front of your shin, or more toward the inside? And does it hurt during activity, after, or both?
My wrist hurts
That can affect your riding. Is it on top of the wrist, underneath, or on the thumb side? And is it worse when bearing weight on the handlebars?
I get cramps
Cramps can have different causes. Where do they usually hit—calves, quads, hamstrings? And do they happen during hard efforts, toward the end of long rides, or at random times?
My knee is bothering me
Let's figure this out together. Is it the front of your knee, the sides, or behind? That'll help me understand what might be causing it.
Front, kind of under the kneecap
Thanks, that's helpful. Does it hurt more when you're pushing hard—like climbing or sprinting—or is it there even on easy efforts?
Mostly when pushing hard, especially climbing

That pattern often points to load-related irritation. For now, let's reduce the climbing and high-force efforts for a week or so. Keep riding but stay in easier gears and flatter terrain. If it doesn't improve, it's worth getting looked at. How does that sound?
I hurt my calf
Sorry to hear that. Did it happen suddenly—like a pop or sharp pain—or has it been building gradually?
It happened suddenly yesterday during a run
That sudden onset matters. How does it feel now—can you walk normally, or is it still quite painful?
I can walk but it's tight and sore

Good that you can walk. With a sudden calf injury, take a few days fully off running—cycling might be okay if it doesn't hurt. If there's significant bruising, swelling, or you can't push off normally after a few days, see a physio. Let's check back in 3-4 days.
Something is wrong with my Achilles
Achilles issues need respect. Is it painful right at the back of your heel, or a bit higher up in the tendon itself?
Higher up, like 2-3 inches above my heel
That's the tendon body. Is it stiff in the morning that loosens up, or does it hurt during and after activity?
Both actually. Stiff mornings and sore after running

That's a classic pattern for tendon irritation. Reduce running volume significantly and avoid hills and speed work for now. Gentle calf raises—slowly lowering down—can help, but don't push into pain. If it's not improving in 2 weeks, see a physio. This one needs patience.
I have pain in my neck and shoulders
That can really affect your riding comfort. Does it come on gradually during rides, or do you start with it already there?
Comes on after maybe 30-40 minutes
That timing often points to position or tension. When it starts, where is it worse—neck, between the shoulder blades, or the tops of your shoulders?
Tops of the shoulders mainly

That's often from gripping the bars too tight or shrugging up when you ride. Try consciously dropping your shoulders every few minutes, and experiment with slightly raising your handlebars if possible. Also check that your reach isn't too long. Small position tweaks often fix this.
My hamstring is tight
Tightness can mean different things. Is it just stiff, or is there actual pain when you stretch or load it?
It's more than just tight—hurts a bit when I really stretch it
That's worth being careful with. Did something specific trigger it, or has it developed over time?
I think I overdid it in a hard session a few days ago

That adds up. Back off the intensity for a week—easy riding is fine but no hard efforts or deep stretching. Gentle movement is good; aggressive stretching often makes these worse. If it's not clearly improving in a week, consider seeing someone. Let it settle before pushing again.
I keep getting saddle sores
Those are no fun. Are they in a consistent spot, or do they move around? And roughly how many hours per week are you riding?
Same spot usually, left side. Riding maybe 8-10 hours
Consistency in location often points to saddle fit or position. Is your saddle level, or could it be tilted? And are you using chamois cream?
I don't use cream and haven't checked if it's level

Good places to start. Get a level and check your saddle—even small tilts can cause friction issues on one side. Start using chamois cream, and make sure your shorts are clean for every ride. Also, standing briefly every 10-15 minutes helps. These changes usually make a big difference.
My lower back hurts after rides
That's common but fixable. Does it hurt during the ride too, or only afterward?
A bit during but worse after
Is your pain central in the spine, or more to one side in the muscles?
More in the muscles on both sides

That's often fatigue from holding position. Your core might be getting tired before your legs do. Off the bike, some basic core work—planks, bird dogs—can help a lot. On the bike, try standing briefly every 15-20 minutes to reset. Also check that your reach isn't too long, which forces more load onto your back.
I have a sharp pain when I breathe deeply
That needs attention. Is it in your chest, your side, or your back? And did it start suddenly or come on gradually?
In my side, came on during a hard effort yesterday
Did you feel anything pull or strain, or did it just appear? And how is it today—better, same, or worse?
Felt like something tweaked. Still there but maybe slightly better

That sounds like it could be a muscle strain between the ribs, which can be painful but usually heals fine. Take it easy for several days—no hard efforts that make you breathe heavily. If it gets worse, spreads, or you feel short of breath, see a doctor to rule out anything else. Check back in a few days.
I have hand numbness
That's worth addressing. Which fingers go numb—the pinky side, the thumb side, or all of them?
Pinky and ring finger mainly
That pattern usually involves the ulnar nerve, which runs along the pinky side of your palm. Does it happen quickly or only on longer rides?
Usually after 45 minutes or so

That nerve gets compressed from gripping or pressure on that part of your hand. Try padded gloves, adjusting your hand position frequently, and checking that your bars aren't tilted down. Also make sure you're not death-gripping the bars. These changes usually help within a few rides.
I think I have a stress fracture
That's serious if true. What makes you think it might be a stress fracture rather than muscle or tendon pain?
It hurts in a very specific spot on my shin and gets worse the more I run
That pattern is concerning. Is there a spot you can press on that's particularly tender—like point tenderness?
Yes, one specific spot about halfway down

Point tenderness that worsens with impact is a red flag for stress fracture. Stop running completely and see a doctor or sports medicine specialist soon—ideally this week. You'll likely need imaging to confirm. Non-impact activity like cycling or swimming might be okay, but get a proper diagnosis first. This isn't something to train through.
Should I train today?
Let me help you decide. How did you sleep last night, and how are your energy levels right now?
I'm not sure if I should do the hard session
Good instinct to pause and think about it. How have the last few days of training felt—manageable, or are you carrying some fatigue?
I feel tired
That's worth paying attention to. Is this the kind of tired that might lift once you start moving, or does it feel deeper than that?
Can I do more than planned?
Maybe—let me ask a couple things first. How have you been recovering lately, and is there a specific reason you want to do more today?
I don't feel like training
That happens to everyone. Is it more mental—just not motivated today—or does your body feel like it needs rest?
I'm stressed
I hear you. Is this a temporary spike, or has stress been elevated for a while? That affects how we should think about training.
Work has been crazy
That takes a toll. Has sleep or recovery been affected, or are you managing to keep those reasonably on track despite work?
I'm not improving
That's frustrating. Help me understand—what are you measuring, and over what timeframe have you noticed this?
I feel flat
Flat can mean different things. Is it physical—legs feel heavy, power is down—or more mental and motivational?
I slept badly
That affects things for sure. Was it one rough night, or has sleep been poor for several days?
I think I'm getting sick
Better to catch that early. What symptoms are you noticing—sore throat, congestion, fatigue, or something else?
Yesterday's workout was really hard
Useful to know. Hard in a good way—you pushed well and felt strong—or hard in a struggling way where you couldn't hit the targets?
I missed a few sessions this week
No problem—life happens. Were they missed by choice, or did something come up that prevented training?
Should I make up the missed workout?
Depends on context. How are you feeling now, and what does the rest of your week look like?
I'm worried I'm overtraining
Let's think through this together. What signs are you noticing that make you concerned?
Should I train today?
Let me help you decide. How did you sleep last night, and how are your energy levels feeling right now?
Slept okay, maybe 6 hours. Feel a bit flat but not terrible
Got it. And how about yesterday's session—did it take a lot out of you, or did you recover well?
It was harder than expected honestly
That's useful to know. With shorter sleep and yesterday feeling harder than planned, today's a good day to go easy. Keep the session light—your body will thank you tomorrow.
I'm not making progress
That's frustrating. Help me understand what you're looking at—is it power numbers, times, how you feel, or something else?
My power hasn't gone up in months
And over those months, what's your training been like—consistent, or has it had interruptions?
Pretty consistent actually, rarely miss sessions

Then we might need to change something. Consistent training without progress often means either the training stimulus needs adjusting, or you need more recovery to let adaptations show. Let's look at adding more variety or a solid recovery week to break the plateau.
I feel terrible today
I'm sorry to hear that. Terrible how—physically exhausted, mentally drained, or something else?
Just wiped out, no energy at all
Has anything been different lately—sleep, stress, eating, or maybe fighting off something?
Now that you mention it, I have had a scratchy throat

That could explain a lot. When your body's fighting something off, energy gets diverted. Skip training today, rest up, and see how you feel tomorrow. If you are getting sick, rest now helps you bounce back faster.
Can I do an extra session?
Maybe—help me understand. How has this week felt so far, and what kind of session are you thinking about adding?
Week's felt good, I want to add another hard interval session
How many hard sessions have you already done this week?
Two

Two hard sessions plus another is getting up there. If you're feeling genuinely good, you could do an easier version of what you're thinking—moderate rather than all-out. But honestly, feeling good is also a fine place to stop. Sometimes it's smarter to bank the good feelings for next week than to push for more.
I haven't been able to hit my intervals lately
That's worth understanding. Are the targets feeling unreachable, or can you start them but fade before finishing?
I can start but fade badly toward the end
And is this new, or has it been happening for a few sessions now?
Last two weeks maybe

Two weeks of fading suggests accumulated fatigue rather than a one-off bad day. I'd recommend a few days of easy training—let your body catch up—then try the intervals again. You're probably not losing fitness; you're just tired. The reset should help.
I feel amazing, can I go harder?
Love the energy! Before we push it, how has this week's training been going—are you coming off easy days, or have you already been working hard?
Had two rest days and feel fresh
That explains the good feeling. What's on the plan for today?
An endurance ride

Feeling fresh on an endurance day is perfect—you can ride with good form and strong technique. I'd suggest keeping it as planned rather than adding intensity. The freshness means tomorrow's hard session will be excellent. Save the energy for when it counts most.
I've been training but not losing weight
Training and weight loss have a complicated relationship. Has your eating changed since you started training more?
I'm hungrier so probably eating more
That's completely normal—training increases appetite. Are you eating more of everything, or mostly reaching for certain foods?
Probably more carbs and snacks

That's a common pattern. Your body wants fuel, which is healthy, but it can offset the calorie burn from training. Small adjustments—more protein to stay fuller, slightly smaller portions—might help, but don't undereat. If weight loss is a priority, we might focus on that during a lower-volume training period rather than trying to do both at once.
Should I skip today because of a bad night's sleep?
One bad night isn't always a deal-breaker. What kind of session is planned for today?
Intervals
How bad was the sleep—just short, or really disrupted?
Woke up multiple times, maybe 4 hours total

Four hours with interruptions is rough. High-intensity work on that little sleep tends to be unproductive—you can't push hard enough for it to count, and it just adds stress. Swap it to an easy session today, and do the intervals when you've slept better. Quality matters more than checking boxes.
I'm struggling mentally with training
That's important to talk about. Is it motivation that's missing, or something heavier like it feeling like a burden?
Training just feels like a chore lately
How long has it felt this way?
Maybe the last month or so

A month of training feeling like a chore is significant. This might be mental fatigue from the routine, or it could be physical fatigue showing up as loss of motivation. Either way, I'd suggest a week of truly optional, just-for-fun riding—no targets, no structure. See if the enjoyment comes back. Sometimes a mental reset is exactly what's needed.
I keep getting sick
That's frustrating and worth understanding. How often has this been happening, and what kind of illnesses?
Like every few weeks, usually colds
Frequent colds often signal an overtaxed immune system. How has your training load been, and are you getting enough sleep?
Training's been heavy, sleep has been short—maybe 6 hours

That combination explains a lot. Heavy training plus inadequate sleep stresses your immune system. Cutting back on training and prioritizing sleep—even adding 30 minutes a night—could break this cycle. Your body is telling you it needs more recovery than it's getting.
I want to get faster
I'd love to help with that. When you picture 'faster'—are you thinking about short, punchy efforts, or holding a higher pace over longer distances? That'll shape what we focus on.
Help me lose weight
I can help with that. Do you have a specific amount in mind, or is it more about how you feel and how clothes fit?
I want to finish a race
Exciting goal! What distance or type of race are you thinking about, and do you have a specific event in mind?
I want to be more consistent
That's a great foundation. What's been getting in the way of consistency—time, motivation, life stuff, or something else?
I want to improve my endurance
Good goal. When you say endurance, are you thinking about going longer than you currently can, or feeling less tired at the distances you already do?
I want to get stronger
Stronger can mean different things. Are you thinking about power on the bike, general strength for life, or something else?
I want to compete
Great ambition! What type of competition interests you, and have you done any races before?
I want to ride a century
That's a meaningful goal. What's the longest ride you've done recently, and do you have a target event or timeline in mind?
I want to get healthier
A worthwhile goal. When you think about 'healthier,' what does that look like for you—more energy, better numbers at the doctor, feeling stronger?
I want to beat my friend
Ha, a little competition can be motivating! At what specifically—a segment, a race, overall fitness? And how far ahead are they currently?
I want to climb better
Climbing is where a lot of people want to improve. Are we talking about short, steep climbs or long, sustained ones? The training focus is a bit different.
I just want to feel better
That's actually a great goal. What does 'feel better' mean to you—more energy, less stress, sleeping better, something else?
I want to qualify for something
Exciting to have a qualification goal. What event or standard are you aiming for, and what's the qualifying requirement?
I want a PR
Love that goal! At what distance or event, and what's your current personal best?
I want to train for fun
That's a perfectly valid approach. What does fun training look like for you—variety, social rides, exploring, achievements, or something else?
I want to get faster
Great goal. Faster at what specifically—short efforts, sustained pace, climbing, overall? And is there a particular timeframe you're thinking about?
I want to hold a faster pace on my long rides
Good clarity. What's your typical long ride pace now, and what would 'faster' look like to you?
I average maybe 18mph, would love to get to 20

18 to 20 mph is achievable—that's building your aerobic engine. The path there is mostly consistent easy riding to build base, with some threshold work mixed in. How much time per week can you commit to training?
I want to do an Ironman
That's a big goal! Have you done any triathlons before, and what's your current fitness baseline in each discipline?
I've done a sprint tri. I can swim okay, bike is my strength, running is weak
Thanks for the honest assessment. And when are you thinking about doing the Ironman—this year, next year, further out?
Maybe 18 months from now

18 months is a solid runway. Given your background, we'd focus early on building running durability safely—that's usually the limiter and the injury risk. Your cycling strength is an advantage. We'd progressively build toward the distances while keeping everything sustainable. It's very doable with smart planning.
I want to lose 20 pounds
That's a specific goal—helpful for planning. What's your timeframe thinking, and what have you tried before?
Maybe 6 months? I've tried cutting calories before but always got too tired to train
That's a common trap—cutting too hard while training hard doesn't work well. How much are you currently training?
Maybe 5-6 hours a week

With that training load, aggressive calorie cuts will definitely backfire. A better approach is moderate deficit—maybe 300-500 calories below maintenance—while keeping training mostly the same. 20 pounds over 6 months is about 0.8 pounds per week, which is sustainable without crushing your energy. Focus on protein and whole foods, don't skip post-workout nutrition.
I want to podium at my local race
That's a concrete, exciting goal. Tell me about the race—what distance and format, and where do you typically finish now?
It's a 40km road race, I usually finish mid-pack
Mid-pack to podium is a significant jump. What do you think separates you from the front—pure fitness, tactical savvy, ability to respond to attacks?
I think my fitness is okay but I fade in the last 10km

Fading late suggests either pacing issues or threshold fitness. We'd focus on building your ability to sustain hard efforts longer and practice reading the race so you're not in the red too early. Some race-specific intensity work plus experience learning when to conserve will help. When's the race?
I want to ride across the country
Wow, that's an adventure! Are you thinking about a supported tour, self-supported, or racing format? And what's your timeline?
Self-supported, maybe next summer
Next summer gives us good time. What's the longest multi-day ride you've done, and how many hours can you comfortably ride in a day currently?
I've done a weekend tour, about 150 miles total. Max day was 80 miles but I was wrecked

Good baseline. Cross-country means many consecutive long days, so we'd build toward sustainable daily mileage—not heroic single days but repeatable efforts. We'd progressively increase your long ride and add back-to-back weekend rides to train your body for consecutive days. The logistics and equipment side matters too, but fitness-wise, this is very buildable.
I just want to keep up with my friends
That's a relatable goal! Where do you tend to get dropped—on climbs, on flat fast sections, or when they attack?
Mostly the climbs, I fall off the back
Climbing is often about power-to-weight and sustained threshold ability. How long are the climbs that cause trouble—short punchy ones or longer sustained ones?
Usually 10-15 minute climbs

That's right in the threshold zone. Building your ability to sustain a hard effort for 10-20 minutes will directly help. We'd include some threshold intervals and sweet spot work, plus long steady rides to build the engine. Depending on your build, dropping a few pounds might help too, but power is usually the bigger lever. How many hours can you train per week?
I want to not be exhausted after every ride
That's a great quality-of-life goal. Tell me about your typical rides—how long, how hard, and how do you feel for the rest of the day?
Usually an hour, I push pretty hard. Then I'm wiped for hours
How often are you riding, and are most rides that same intensity?
Four or five times a week, and yeah, I usually go hard

That's likely the issue. Going hard every ride never lets your body fully recover, so you're always training on fatigue. The fix is counterintuitive: ride easier most of the time. Make 3-4 of those rides truly easy—conversational pace—and only 1-2 actually hard. You'll recover better, feel less wiped, and probably get faster too. The easy days make the hard days work.
I want to set a good example for my kids
That's a wonderful motivation. What does setting a good example look like for you—being active, achieving goals, showing discipline, something else?
Showing them that health matters and that you can do hard things
I love that. Do you have a specific physical goal in mind, or is it more about demonstrating consistent healthy habits?
Maybe finishing an event they could come watch
That's a perfect goal—tangible, something they can cheer for, and meaningful. What kind of event appeals to you, and what's realistic given your current fitness and available time?
I don't understand zones

Let me try a different way. Think of zones like speeds on your car: Zone 1-2 is cruising—you could drive like this all day. Zone 4-5 is floor it—you can't sustain it long. Does that framing help, or would another angle be more useful?
What do you mean by threshold?

Good question. Threshold is the intensity you could hold for about an hour at maximum effort—hard but manageable. Above it, you quickly run out of steam. Below it, you can go much longer. Does that make sense?
I don't get why easy should be so easy

It does feel counterintuitive. Here's the idea: easy training builds your aerobic base without creating fatigue. If 'easy' feels like work, you're using energy that should be saved for hard days. Think of it as investing in your foundation. Does that logic track for you?
What's recovery actually mean?

Recovery is when your body repairs and adapts from training stress. During hard workouts you're actually breaking down—recovery is when you build back stronger. That's why rest isn't wasted time; it's when the improvement actually happens. Want me to expand on any part of that?
Why do you keep saying periodization?

Sorry for the jargon. Periodization just means varying your training over time in a structured way—like building fitness in blocks rather than doing the same thing forever. Basically: push, recover, push harder, recover. Does that clarify it?
I don't understand why I need rest days

Here's a way to think about it: training is like digging a hole, rest is like filling it in and building a small hill. Without rest, you just keep digging deeper. The hill—your fitness—only gets built when you stop digging. Make sense?
What does 'base' mean?

Base fitness is your aerobic foundation—like the foundation of a house. It's built with lots of easy, consistent training. A bigger base lets you build more on top of it later. Without it, harder training doesn't stick as well. Is that clearer?
Why do you change my plan?

Plans are starting points, not rigid scripts. I adjust based on how you're actually responding—if you need more recovery, or if you're handling things better than expected. The goal is optimal training for you right now, not following a plan for its own sake. Does that make sense?
What do you mean by intensity?

Intensity is how hard an effort is—not how long, but how much you're pushing. Walking is low intensity, sprinting is high intensity. In training, we mix different intensities for different purposes. Want me to explain why different intensities matter?
I'm confused about when to push and when to rest

Simple rule of thumb: push when you feel fresh and the plan says hard. Rest when you feel genuinely tired or the plan says easy. If there's a conflict—you feel tired but the plan says hard—usually listen to your body. Does that help as a starting framework?
What's the difference between tired and overtrained?

Good question. Tired from a hard workout clears in a day or two with rest. Overtraining is deep fatigue that doesn't clear—it persists for weeks despite rest, often with mood changes and performance decline. Normal tired is part of training; overtraining is training gone wrong. Does that distinction make sense?
Why do some workouts have intervals?

Intervals let you accumulate time at hard intensities you couldn't sustain continuously. Five 5-minute hard efforts with recovery between gives you 25 minutes of hard work—you couldn't do 25 minutes straight that hard. The recovery breaks make it possible. Clearer?
I don't understand my readiness

Think of readiness as a traffic light for training. Green means go—you're recovered and ready for anything. Amber means caution—train but skip the hardest efforts. Red means stop hard training and recover. It's based on your recent load and recovery. Does that framing help?
What does 'listen to your body' actually mean?

It means paying attention to signals like fatigue, motivation, aches, and energy levels—and adjusting accordingly. Not every signal means stop, but persistent signals matter. It's about being aware and making informed decisions rather than blindly following a plan. Want me to give examples of signals to watch for?
Why can't I just train hard every day?

Because improvement happens during recovery, not during the workout itself. Training hard breaks you down; rest builds you back stronger. Hard every day means you're always breaking down and never building up—you get slower, not faster. The rest is where the magic happens. Does that logic make sense?
I still don't understand threshold

Let me try again. Imagine you're holding your breath underwater. Threshold is like the point where you're almost out of air but can just barely hold on—sustainable but hard. Above threshold, you're out of air fast. Below it, you could hold much longer. Does that analogy help?
Kind of, but how do I know where mine is?

Good question. A simple test: it's roughly the pace you could hold for an hour all-out. In terms of feel, it's where talking becomes very difficult but you're not gasping. Hard but controlled. Ring any bells from your training?
Yeah I think I know that feeling

Perfect—that's threshold. Some workouts will target that zone specifically because improving your threshold means you can go faster before hitting that 'running out of air' feeling. Does that connect?
You keep saying polarized training but I don't know what that means

Sorry, let me explain. Polarized training means spending most of your time at easy intensities and a smaller portion at hard intensities—with not much in the middle. Think 80% easy, 20% hard. Does that basic split make sense?
Why not train in the middle?

Great question. Middle-zone training is hard enough to tire you out but not hard enough to create a strong adaptation signal. Easy training lets you recover and build base. Hard training forces big adaptations. Middle gives you the fatigue without the full benefit of either extreme.
So the middle is a trap?

Exactly—some people call it the 'gray zone.' It's where a lot of people naturally train because easy feels too easy and hard is uncomfortable. But the contrast between genuinely easy and genuinely hard is what produces the best results. Nice way to put it.
I don't understand why I'm amber when I feel fine

Readiness looks at patterns your body might not consciously feel yet—like accumulated load over days. Sometimes you feel fine but fatigue is building under the surface. Think of it as an early warning system. Does that framing help?
Sort of. So I might feel it tomorrow if I push today?
Exactly. Amber is saying 'you might get away with it today, but there's a cost coming.' If you push hard on amber repeatedly, the fatigue catches up. Better to respect it now than pay for it later.
Okay that makes more sense
Good. Your feeling is still valuable information—just consider it alongside readiness. When they disagree, going with the more cautious signal is usually wise.
I don't get what supercompensation means

Let me break it down simply. When you train hard, your fitness actually dips temporarily—you're tired. Then you rest, and your body rebuilds. But it doesn't just return to where you were; it builds a bit higher, preparing for future stress. That overshoot is supercompensation. Make sense?
So you get stronger during rest, not during the workout?
Exactly right. The workout provides the stimulus—the signal to adapt. The actual adaptation happens during recovery. That's why skipping rest undermines the whole process.
And if you train again before recovering?

You start from a lower point and dig the hole deeper. Without recovery between, you just keep depleting without rebuilding. Eventually you're way below baseline instead of above it. That's how overtraining happens. You've got it.
What does FTP mean and why does it matter?

FTP stands for Functional Threshold Power—basically the power you could sustain for about an hour at maximum effort. It matters because training zones are often set as percentages of it. Does that basic definition help, or do you want more detail?
How do I know what mine is?

You can estimate it through a test—often a 20-minute all-out effort, then take 95% of the average power. Or some apps estimate it from your training data over time. Have you done any all-out efforts we could look at?
I haven't really tested it formally

No problem. If you have a power meter, we can do a test when you're fresh, or we can estimate from your hard efforts in training. The exact number matters less than having a reasonable baseline to set your zones. Want to schedule a test, or work from estimates for now?
I don't really understand TSS

TSS is Training Stress Score—a way to quantify how much a workout took out of you by combining duration and intensity. Higher TSS means more stress. Think of it like a cost number for each session. Does that basic idea land?
So a long easy ride and a short hard ride could have the same TSS?

Exactly—they're different ways to accumulate the same total stress. The type of stress differs, but the overall load on your body might be similar. That's why TSS is useful for tracking total load over time.
But they feel really different

You're right, and that's a limitation. TSS captures total load but not the type of fatigue. A hard interval session might feel more draining even at the same TSS as an endurance ride. Use TSS as one tool, not the only one. Your feel matters too.
Why do you call some rides recovery rides if I'm still riding?

Good question—it sounds contradictory. The idea is that very easy movement actually helps recovery compared to sitting still. Easy spinning increases blood flow, which clears waste products and brings nutrients to muscles. As long as it's easy enough not to add stress, it helps rather than hurts.
How easy is easy enough?
Easy enough that you could chat normally throughout. No burning legs, no heavy breathing, no feeling like you're working. If it feels like exercise, it's probably too hard to count as recovery.
That feels really slow

It should. Recovery rides often feel frustratingly slow, especially if you're used to pushing. The purpose isn't fitness building—it's recovery acceleration. Trust that the slowness is the point, and your hard days will be better for it.
What's the difference between volume and intensity?

Volume is how much you do—hours, miles, total work. Intensity is how hard each bit is. You can have high volume at low intensity (lots of easy riding) or low volume at high intensity (short, hard sessions). Both stress your body, but differently. Clear?
Which is more important?

Neither wins outright—you need some of both. But for most people, volume at low intensity builds the foundation, and intensity provides the sharpening. Too much intensity without base volume burns you out. Too much volume without intensity leaves you slow. Balance matters.
How do I know if I need more of one?

If you're always tired but not fast, you might need less intensity and more easy volume or rest. If you have good endurance but lack top-end speed, you might need more intensity. Your response to training and your goals guide the balance. Does that help you think about your situation?
I don't get why deload weeks help

Think of it like this: during hard training, your fitness is building but so is fatigue. Fatigue masks fitness—you're fitter but can't show it because you're tired. Deload weeks let fatigue drop while fitness stays. Then you can actually express the fitness you've built. Make sense?
So I'm not losing fitness during deload?

Right—fitness takes longer to decline than fatigue takes to clear. A week of easier training barely touches your fitness but dramatically reduces accumulated tiredness. You come back feeling stronger because the fatigue mask is lifted.
Why don't I just deload all the time then?

Ha, good question. Because without the hard training that creates fatigue, there's no fitness stimulus to reveal. You need the hard work to build fitness; you need the deload to realize it. The cycle of stress and recovery is what produces improvement.
I don't understand why slow makes you fast

It does sound backwards! Here's the logic: slow training builds your aerobic engine—more capillaries, more mitochondria, better fat burning. This foundation lets you go harder when you need to because your base can support it. Without the slow work, hard training has nothing to build on. Click?
So it's building the engine, not the speed?
Exactly. Slow training builds the engine. Fast training tunes it for performance. A bigger engine tuned up beats a small engine tuned up. Both matter, but the engine comes first.
That makes more sense now
Good. It's why elite athletes spend so much time going easy—they're building massive engines. Then the hard work makes those engines fast. The patience for slow work is what enables the fast results.
What do you mean when you say 'listen to your body'?

I know it sounds vague. Specifically, I mean notice things like: Are you more tired than usual? Is your motivation low? Are familiar efforts feeling harder? Any unusual aches? These signals help you know when to push and when to back off. Want me to give more specific examples?
Yeah, like what should I actually watch for?

Watch for: legs feeling heavy at the start of a ride, requiring more effort for usual paces, not sleeping well despite being tired, dreading training you normally enjoy, or small aches becoming persistent. Any of those are signals worth heeding.
And what do I do when I notice them?

Usually, ease back. If you notice one signal for one day, maybe train easy instead of hard. If multiple signals persist for several days, take extra rest. The signals are early warnings—responding early prevents bigger problems.
Why do you care so much about sleep?

Sleep is when most of your recovery happens—muscle repair, hormone release, memory consolidation. Poor sleep directly impairs all of that. You can do everything else right, but if sleep is consistently short, your training can't fully pay off. Does that explain why I keep mentioning it?
I guess. But I function fine on 6 hours

You might function, but are you thriving? Research consistently shows most people need 7-9 hours for optimal recovery from training. Functioning on less often means operating below your potential. What's keeping sleep short—time, habit, or something else?
Just staying up too late usually

That's the most fixable reason. Even adding 30 minutes—going to bed slightly earlier—can make a noticeable difference over time. Think of it as free performance gains. Worth trying for a couple weeks to see how you feel?
